Hammer 0.2.0 API

Overview

See: Description

Packages 
Package Description
hammer.api
The classes and interfaces that make up the API surface of the Hammer framework.

Overview

The Hammer Framework is a fully compliant JSR-330 dependency injection implementation. It is a lighter weight alternative to other popular JSR-330 implementations such as Guice, Spring, HK2, and others. In addition to its leaner API and simpler configuration, it has a smaller runtime footprint of most of the alternatives and a faster runtime bootstrapping time.

Features

  • Fully compliant JSR-330 implementation supporting the full specification
  • Passes the official JSR-330 TCK
  • Lean and compact API surface
  • Can enforce restricted injection types (e.g. only public constructor injection)
  • Supports custom Scopes that can be entered/exited
  • First class citizen support of injecting collection types

Usage

Basic Injection

The Injector is the main dependency injection interface for the hammer framework. In order to acquire an instance of an Injector, a single Container instance is configured and manipulated using one or more Loader implementations. This all happens in the context of a call to one of the static Hammer.createInjector methods which returns a fully configured and ready to use Injector.

The Container is configured by adding injectable concrete classes (or fully instantiated instances) via the addImpl or addInstance methods. These calls can then be further configured to indicate under what conditions the configured injectable class will be injected (i.e. for what types and qualifiers). For example, consider the following concrete class which is legally injectable according to the rules of the JSR-330 specification: 

  public class GameService implements Service {
    private final Handicapper handicapper;

    @Inject
    GameService(Handicapper handicapper) {
      this.handicapper = handicapper;
    }

    public Game startGame(Player... players) {
      ...
    }

    @Override
    public void start() { ... }

    @Override
    public void stop() { ... }
  }

Injectable Value (via concrete class type, no qualifier)

In order to inject a GameService, it must be added to the Container using a Loader. Since it also depends on a Handicapper, an implementation of that type must also be added to the container: 

  public class GameLoader implements Loader {
    @Override
    public void load(Container container) {
      // configure the GameService to be injected for requests of its own type
      container.addImplType(GameService.class)
               .asStrictBinding()
               .forItself();

      // configure a FairHandicapper to be injected for requests of a Handicapper
      container.addImplType(FairHandicapper.class)
               .asStrictBinding()
               .forSpecificTypes(Handicapper.class);
    }
  });

Using the above Loader, an Injector can be created and used to acquire an instance of GameService: 

  public static void main(String[] args) {

    // configure the container and create the injector
    Injector injector = Hammer.createInjector(new GameLoader());

    // get an instance of GameService
    GameService gs = injector.getInstance(GameService.class);
  }

Injectable Value (via interface type, no qualifier)

Notice that the GameService is injected "forItself" in the above Loader. Rather than configuring the injector to inject it for requests of its own type, you can also configure the GameService to be injected for requests of Service instances: 

  container.addImplType(GameService.class).asStrictBinding().forSpecificTypes(Service.class);

Now injection requests for an instance of Service will return a GameService. 

  // will be an instance of GameService
  Service gs = injector.getInstance(Service.class);

Injectable Value (via either class or interface type with qualifier)

Injections using qualifiers are fully supported with hammer. In order to configure an injection request to be associated with a specific qualifier, use the whenQualifiedBy method that is fluently available when setting up strict bindings: 

  // configure a FairHandicapper to be injected for requests of a Handicapper
  // that are qualified with an @Named("fair") qualifier annotation
  container.addImplType(FairHandicapper.class)
           .asStrictBinding()
           .forSpecificTypes(Handicapper.class)
           .whenQualifiedWith(Qualifiers.named("fair"));

Injecting Parameterized Types

Configuring parameterized types is supported by using the TypeToken class available in the API. For example: 

  container.addImplType(MyIntegerSet.class)
           .asStrictBinding()
           .forSpecificTypes(new TypeToken<Set<Integer>>() {});

Static Injection

Static injection is supported at Injector creation time via calls to the Container.configureStaticInjections(java.lang.Class<?>) method.

Collection Injection

See the Container class and its nested classes for more details on collection injection.

Using Scopes

See the Container.activateScopes(java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.annotation.Annotation>...) method and the Injector.enterScope(java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.annotation.Annotation>) method for more details on support for scopes.
